title: Energy Bills Going Down in April
summary: In April, many families in England, Wales, and Scotland will pay less for their energy bills. The government and a group called Ofgem have made changes to lower the costs. For a typical home, the bill might drop by about £10 each month. This is because the government stopped an old program and moved some charges to taxes. However, bills are still higher than before the war in Ukraine, and people are encouraged to look for better deals to save more money. The Prime Minister says he wants to help people with their bills, but others argue that moving costs to taxes might not be fair. The exact savings depend on how much energy a family uses.

background_read: Energy bills are what families pay for electricity and gas to power their homes. In the UK, a group called Ofgem sets rules to make sure energy companies charge fair prices. The government makes decisions that can affect these bills, like changing programs or taxes. Recently, bills have been high because of events like the war in Ukraine, so lowering them helps people save money. Understanding this helps see how leaders work to help with living costs.
Article_Structure: WHO: Ofgem and the government announced the change, with Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer and Claire Coutinho giving opinions.
WHAT: Energy bills will fall by about £10 a month for typical homes in April due to policy changes.
WHERE: This affects households in England, Wales, and Scotland.
WHY: To reduce living costs, though some argue moving charges to taxes might not be fair.

perspectives.description: The government says lowering bills helps people with high costs and keeps promises.
Others argue that moving costs to taxes hides the true cost and might not help everyone fairly.
